title: How to Grill Yellowtail

steps.headline: Place the herbs, garlic, shallots, red pepper, and juice in a blender.
steps.description: While it's fine to use the stems of the cilantro, you should only use the leaves of the parsley and oregano. Avoid using dried herbs in this marinade since the flavor won't be as intense.

steps.headline: Blend the olive oil into the marinade.
steps.description: Put the lid on the blender and pulse it until the mixture becomes thick and smooth. Slowly pour in 1 cup (240 ml) of olive oil while the blender is running. The marinade should be thin enough to pour once the oil is incorporated.

steps.headline: Cover and marinate the yellowtail for at least 30 minutes.
steps.description: Place the yellowtail fillets in a shallow container. Pour the marinade over the fish and put the dish in the refrigerator. Chill the yellowtail for 30 to 45 minutes. Avoid marinating the fish in a metallic container or it could flavor the fish.

steps.headline: Heat a gas or charcoal grill to high.
steps.description: Turn on a gas grill to high or light a chimney full of charcoal briquettes, if you're using a charcoal grill. When the briquettes are hot and ashy, dump them in on one side of the grill grate.

steps.headline: Lay the marinated yellowtail on the grill and sprinkle it with salt.
steps.description: Remove the yellowtail from the refrigerator and lay the fillets on the preheated grill. Leave at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) of space between the fillets. If you're using a charcoal grill, arrange them directly over the briquettes. Sprinkle a little sea salt over each fillet.

steps.headline: Grill the yellowtail for 2 to 3 minutes.
steps.description: Cover the grill and cook the yellowtail on 1 side.

steps.headline: Flip and grill the yellowtail for 2 to 3 more minutes.
steps.description: Use a fish spatula or tongs to flip each fillet over. Put the lid back on the grill and cook the fillets for another 2 to 3 minutes. You should see grill marks on each side of the fillets.

steps.headline: Move the fillets to indirect heat, if you're using a charcoal grill.
steps.description: Remove the lid and transfer the fillets to the cool side of the grill.

steps.headline: Cover the grill and cook the yellowtail for 4 to 7 more minutes.
steps.description: Grill the yellowtail until the fish flakes easily when you drag a fork across it.

steps.headline: Serve the grilled yellowtail.
steps.description: Transfer the fillets to a platter and serve the fish immediately. Consider serving the fish with risotto, rice pilaf, or grilled vegetables. Store the leftover yellowtail in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 3 to 4 days.

steps.headline: Whisk the garlic, olive oil, lime juice, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Measure the lemon-garlic marinade ingredients in a small bowl. Whisk the mixture until it's combined and smooth.

steps.headline: Lay the yellowtail in a shallow dish and cover it with the marinade.
steps.description: Arrange 2 ⁄4 pounds (1.2 kg) of skinless yellowtail fillets in the shallow dish and pour the lemon-garlic over the fillets so they're completely coated.

steps.headline: Marinade the fish for 30 minutes at room temperature.
steps.description: Set the fish aside to marinate while you prepare the grill.

steps.headline: Heat the gas or charcoal grill to medium-high.
steps.description: Turn on the gas grill or heat a chimney full of charcoal briquettes, if you're using a charcoal grill. Dump the briquettes when they're hot and ashy. Spread the ashes on 1 side of the grill grate to make a 2-zone fire.

steps.headline: Lay the fish on the grill over direct heat.
steps.description: Remove the yellowfish from the marinade and lay the fillets on the grill so they're at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart. If you're using the charcoal grill, place them directly over the coals.

steps.headline: Grill the yellowfish for 2 minutes.
steps.description: Cover the grill and let the fish cook until it becomes brown on the bottom. You should be able to see grill marks.

steps.headline: Flip and grill the fish for 2 more minutes.
steps.description: Lift the grill lid and use a fish spatula or tongs to flip each fillet over. Put the lid back down and grill the fish for 2 more minutes.

steps.headline: Move the fish to indirect heat and grill it for 3 to 4 minutes.
steps.description: If you're using a gas grill, lift the lid and move the fish to the cooler side of the grill. Put the lid back down and grill the fish until it flakes easily. If you're using a gas grill, you don't need to move the fish. Just cook the fish until it's flaky.

steps.headline: Serve the lemon-garlic yellowtail.
steps.description: Remove the fish from the grill and place it on a platter. Serve the fish immediately with pasta, grilled vegetables, or couscous. Refrigerate the leftover yellowtail in an airtight container for 3 to 4 days.

steps.headline: Heat a charcoal or gas grill to medium.
steps.description: Turn on the gas grill or heat 1/2 of a chimney full of charcoal briquettes. Dump the hot, ashy briquettes onto the center of the grill grate.

steps.headline: Combine the ancho chile powder, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Measure the seasonings in a small bowl and use a whisk or spoon to combine them.

steps.headline: Season both sides of the yellowtail fillets with oil and ancho seasoning.
steps.description: Get out 4 fish fillets and brush 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of vegetable oil over each fillet. Divide the ancho seasoning among the fish and use your fingers or a spoon to coat both sides of the fillets with the seasoning.

steps.headline: Lay the yellowtail on the grill and cook it for 3 minutes.
steps.description: Arrange the fillets on the hot grill grate and put the lid on the grill. Cook the fish until it browns on the bottom.

steps.headline: Flip and grill the yellowtail for 3 more minutes.
steps.description: Lift the lid of the grill and use a fish spatula or tongs to flip each fillet over. Put the lid back down and grill the fish for 3 more minutes, so it flakes easily.

steps.headline: Serve the spiced yellowtail.
steps.description: Move the grilled fish to a platter and serve it immediately. Try serving the fish with mango salsa, hot green curry, or rice. Store the leftovers in an airtight container. Refrigerate them for 3 to 4 days.

text: Herb-Marinated Grilled Yellowtail Place the herbs, garlic, shallots, red pepper, and juice in a blender. While it's fine to use the stems of the cilantro, you should only use the leaves of the parsley and oregano. Avoid using dried herbs in this marinade since the flavor won't be as intense. Blend the olive oil into the marinade. Put the lid on the blender and pulse it until the mixture becomes thick and smooth. Slowly pour in 1 cup (240 ml) of olive oil while the blender is running. The marinade should be thin enough to pour once the oil is incorporated. Cover and marinate the yellowtail for at least 30 minutes. Place the yellowtail fillets in a shallow container. Pour the marinade over the fish and put the dish in the refrigerator. Chill the yellowtail for 30 to 45 minutes. Avoid marinating the fish in a metallic container or it could flavor the fish. Heat a gas or charcoal grill to high. Turn on a gas grill to high or light a chimney full of charcoal briquettes, if you're using a charcoal grill. When the briquettes are hot and ashy, dump them in on one side of the grill grate. Lay the marinated yellowtail on the grill and sprinkle it with salt. Remove the yellowtail from the refrigerator and lay the fillets on the preheated grill. Leave at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) of space between the fillets. If you're using a charcoal grill, arrange them directly over the briquettes. Sprinkle a little sea salt over each fillet. Grill the yellowtail for 2 to 3 minutes. Cover the grill and cook the yellowtail on 1 side. Flip and grill the yellowtail for 2 to 3 more minutes. Use a fish spatula or tongs to flip each fillet over. Put the lid back on the grill and cook the fillets for another 2 to 3 minutes. You should see grill marks on each side of the fillets. Move the fillets to indirect heat, if you're using a charcoal grill. Remove the lid and transfer the fillets to the cool side of the grill. Cover the grill and cook the yellowtail for 4 to 7 more minutes. Grill the yellowtail until the fish flakes easily when you drag a fork across it. Serve the grilled yellowtail. Transfer the fillets to a platter and serve the fish immediately. Consider serving the fish with risotto, rice pilaf, or grilled vegetables. Store the leftover yellowtail in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 3 to 4 days. Lemon-Garlic Grilled Yellowtail Whisk the garlic, olive oil, lime juice, salt, and pepper. Measure the lemon-garlic marinade ingredients in a small bowl. Whisk the mixture until it's combined and smooth. Lay the yellowtail in a shallow dish and cover it with the marinade. Arrange 2 ⁄4 pounds (1.2 kg) of skinless yellowtail fillets in the shallow dish and pour the lemon-garlic over the fillets so they're completely coated. Marinade the fish for 30 minutes at room temperature. Set the fish aside to marinate while you prepare the grill. Heat the gas or charcoal grill to medium-high. Turn on the gas grill or heat a chimney full of charcoal briquettes, if you're using a charcoal grill. Dump the briquettes when they're hot and ashy. Spread the ashes on 1 side of the grill grate to make a 2-zone fire. Lay the fish on the grill over direct heat. Remove the yellowfish from the marinade and lay the fillets on the grill so they're at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart. If you're using the charcoal grill, place them directly over the coals. Grill the yellowfish for 2 minutes. Cover the grill and let the fish cook until it becomes brown on the bottom. You should be able to see grill marks. Flip and grill the fish for 2 more minutes. Lift the grill lid and use a fish spatula or tongs to flip each fillet over. Put the lid back down and grill the fish for 2 more minutes. Move the fish to indirect heat and grill it for 3 to 4 minutes. If you're using a gas grill, lift the lid and move the fish to the cooler side of the grill. Put the lid back down and grill the fish until it flakes easily. If you're using a gas grill, you don't need to move the fish. Just cook the fish until it's flaky. Serve the lemon-garlic yellowtail. Remove the fish from the grill and place it on a platter. Serve the fish immediately with pasta, grilled vegetables, or couscous. Refrigerate the leftover yellowtail in an airtight container for 3 to 4 days. Spiced Grilled Yellowtail Heat a charcoal or gas grill to medium. Turn on the gas grill or heat 1/2 of a chimney full of charcoal briquettes. Dump the hot, ashy briquettes onto the center of the grill grate. Combine the ancho chile powder, salt, and pepper. Measure the seasonings in a small bowl and use a whisk or spoon to combine them. Season both sides of the yellowtail fillets with oil and ancho seasoning. Get out 4 fish fillets and brush 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of vegetable oil over each fillet. Divide the ancho seasoning among the fish and use your fingers or a spoon to coat both sides of the fillets with the seasoning. Lay the yellowtail on the grill and cook it for 3 minutes. Arrange the fillets on the hot grill grate and put the lid on the grill. Cook the fish until it browns on the bottom. Flip and grill the yellowtail for 3 more minutes. Lift the lid of the grill and use a fish spatula or tongs to flip each fillet over. Put the lid back down and grill the fish for 3 more minutes, so it flakes easily. Serve the spiced yellowtail. Move the grilled fish to a platter and serve it immediately. Try serving the fish with mango salsa, hot green curry, or rice. Store the leftovers in an airtight container. Refrigerate them for 3 to 4 days.
sentences: Herb-Marinated Grilled Yellowtail Place the herbs, garlic, shallots, red pepper, and juice in a blender.
While it's fine to use the stems of the cilantro, you should only use the leaves of the parsley and oregano.
Avoid using dried herbs in this marinade since the flavor won't be as intense.
Blend the olive oil into the marinade.
Put the lid on the blender and pulse it until the mixture becomes thick and smooth.
Slowly pour in 1 cup (240 ml) of olive oil while the blender is running.
The marinade should be thin enough to pour once the oil is incorporated.
Cover and marinate the yellowtail for at least 30 minutes.
Place the yellowtail fillets in a shallow container.
Pour the marinade over the fish and put the dish in the refrigerator.
Chill the yellowtail for 30 to 45 minutes.
Avoid marinating the fish in a metallic container or it could flavor the fish.
Heat a gas or charcoal grill to high.
Turn on a gas grill to high or light a chimney full of charcoal briquettes, if you're using a charcoal grill.
When the briquettes are hot and ashy, dump them in on one side of the grill grate.
Lay the marinated yellowtail on the grill and sprinkle it with salt.
Remove the yellowtail from the refrigerator and lay the fillets on the preheated grill.
Leave at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) of space between the fillets.
If you're using a charcoal grill, arrange them directly over the briquettes.
Sprinkle a little sea salt over each fillet.
Grill the yellowtail for 2 to 3 minutes.
Cover the grill and cook the yellowtail on 1 side.
Flip and grill the yellowtail for 2 to 3 more minutes.
Use a fish spatula or tongs to flip each fillet over.
Put the lid back on the grill and cook the fillets for another 2 to 3 minutes.
You should see grill marks on each side of the fillets.
Move the fillets to indirect heat, if you're using a charcoal grill.
Remove the lid and transfer the fillets to the cool side of the grill.
Cover the grill and cook the yellowtail for 4 to 7 more minutes.
Grill the yellowtail until the fish flakes easily when you drag a fork across it.
Serve the grilled yellowtail.
Transfer the fillets to a platter and serve the fish immediately.
Consider serving the fish with risotto, rice pilaf, or grilled vegetables.
Store the leftover yellowtail in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 3 to 4 days.
Lemon-Garlic Grilled Yellowtail Whisk the garlic, olive oil, lime juice, salt, and pepper.
Measure the lemon-garlic marinade ingredients in a small bowl.
Whisk the mixture until it's combined and smooth.
Lay the yellowtail in a shallow dish and cover it with the marinade.
Arrange 2 ⁄4 pounds (1.2 kg) of skinless yellowtail fillets in the shallow dish and pour the lemon-garlic over the fillets so they're completely coated.
Marinade the fish for 30 minutes at room temperature.
Set the fish aside to marinate while you prepare the grill.
Heat the gas or charcoal grill to medium-high.
Turn on the gas grill or heat a chimney full of charcoal briquettes, if you're using a charcoal grill.
Dump the briquettes when they're hot and ashy.
Spread the ashes on 1 side of the grill grate to make a 2-zone fire.
Lay the fish on the grill over direct heat.
Remove the yellowfish from the marinade and lay the fillets on the grill so they're at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart.
If you're using the charcoal grill, place them directly over the coals.
Grill the yellowfish for 2 minutes.
Cover the grill and let the fish cook until it becomes brown on the bottom.
You should be able to see grill marks.
Flip and grill the fish for 2 more minutes.
Lift the grill lid and use a fish spatula or tongs to flip each fillet over.
Put the lid back down and grill the fish for 2 more minutes.
Move the fish to indirect heat and grill it for 3 to 4 minutes.
If you're using a gas grill, lift the lid and move the fish to the cooler side of the grill.
Put the lid back down and grill the fish until it flakes easily.
If you're using a gas grill, you don't need to move the fish.
Just cook the fish until it's flaky.
Serve the lemon-garlic yellowtail.
Remove the fish from the grill and place it on a platter.
Serve the fish immediately with pasta, grilled vegetables, or couscous.
Refrigerate the leftover yellowtail in an airtight container for 3 to 4 days.
Spiced Grilled Yellowtail Heat a charcoal or gas grill to medium.
Turn on the gas grill or heat 1/2 of a chimney full of charcoal briquettes.
Dump the hot, ashy briquettes onto the center of the grill grate.
Combine the ancho chile powder, salt, and pepper.
Measure the seasonings in a small bowl and use a whisk or spoon to combine them.
Season both sides of the yellowtail fillets with oil and ancho seasoning.
Get out 4 fish fillets and brush 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of vegetable oil over each fillet.
Divide the ancho seasoning among the fish and use your fingers or a spoon to coat both sides of the fillets with the seasoning.
Lay the yellowtail on the grill and cook it for 3 minutes.
Arrange the fillets on the hot grill grate and put the lid on the grill.
Cook the fish until it browns on the bottom.
Flip and grill the yellowtail for 3 more minutes.
Lift the lid of the grill and use a fish spatula or tongs to flip each fillet over.
Put the lid back down and grill the fish for 3 more minutes, so it flakes easily.
Serve the spiced yellowtail.
Move the grilled fish to a platter and serve it immediately.
Try serving the fish with mango salsa, hot green curry, or rice.
Store the leftovers in an airtight container.
Refrigerate them for 3 to 4 days.
